title: 107_hr2967
content: Duty-free treatment for certain foodstuffs from NAFTA countries. Amendments to U.S. Notes regarding certain food preparations from Canada or Mexico under subheading 9802.00.95, exempting them from duty and tariff-rate quota provisions. The term 'product of Canada or Mexico' refers to goods determined under rules of origin in the North American Free Trade Agreement, processed or improved in value in Canada or Mexico, and recognized as products of the United States. The term 'product of the United States' is defined as a good or material determined under rules of origin in the North American Free Trade Agreement. This includes goods processed in Canada or Mexico using materials exported from the United States. The Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States is amended to allow duty-free treatment for goods processed in Canada or Mexico using materials from the United States, as long as the processing does not change the country of origin. The Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States allows duty-free treatment for goods processed in Canada or Mexico using materials from the United States, as long as the processing does not change the country of origin. The Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States allows duty-free treatment for goods processed in Canada or Mexico using materials from the United States, as long as the processing does not change the country of origin. The originating good must satisfy the requirements of General Note 12 of the tariff schedule, and any material used in processing must be a product of the United States and produced from quota peanuts as defined in section 358-1 of the Agriculture. The Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States allows duty-free treatment for goods processed in Canada or Mexico using materials from the United States, as long as the processing does not change the country of origin. The originating good must satisfy the requirements of General Note 12 of the tariff schedule, and any material used in processing must be a product of the United States and produced from quota peanuts as defined in section 358-1 of the Agriculture Adjustment Act of 1938. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) of the Act will apply to goods entered or withdrawn from warehouse for consumption 15 days after the enactment date.
